{{Politics of Egypt}}
{{Politics of Egypt}}
â
A '''presidential election''' is expected to be held in [[Egypt]] on September 2011;<ref name="2011 ELECTORAL CALENDAR">[http://www.angelfire.com/ma/maxcrc/2011.html 2011 ELECTORAL CALENDAR]</ref><ref name="IFES Election Guide">[http://www.electionguide.org/country.php?ID=65 IFES Election Guide]</ref> it will be the second contested presidential election in Egypt's history. [[Hosni Mubarak]], the [[incumbent]] [[Rulers and heads of state of Egypt|President of Egypt]], may not run for this election which opens the door for many names to be suggested to take his place as President of Egypt. Some of those names are [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] (the ex-Director General of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA), and the winner of the 2005 [[Nobel Peace Prize]]), [[Amr Moussa]] (the current [[Secretary-General]] of the [[League of Arab States]], and former [[Egypt]]ian [[Foreign Minister]]), [[Ahmed Zewail]] ([[Egyptians|Egyptian]]-[[United States|American]] scientist, and the winner of the 1999 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]]), and [[Gamal Mubarak]] (the General Secretary of the Policy Committee of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] and the younger of the two sons of Hosni Mubarak), among others. Leading figures in the [[History of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] ''(Egyptian biggest opposition group)''{{Citation needed|December 2009|date=December 2009}} has refused to go into Egypt's presidential election even if they get the legal requirements <ref name="Leading figures in the Muslim Brotherhood: We will not go into Egypt's presidential election, even if we got the legal requirements">[http://www.aawsat.com/details.asp?section=4&issueno=10684&article=460508&feature= Leading figures in the Muslim Brotherhood: We will not go into Egypt's presidential election, even if we got the legal requirements]</ref> and refused women and Copts run for presidency again <ref name="Muslim Brotherhood refuse women and Copts run for presidency again">[http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=146188 Muslim Brotherhood refuse women and Copts run for presidency again]</ref> or support any candidates so far.
+
A '''presidential election''' is expected to be held in [[Egypt]] on September 2011;<ref name="2011 ELECTORAL CALENDAR">[http://www.angelfire.com/ma/maxcrc/2011.html 2011 ELECTORAL CALENDAR]</ref><ref name="IFES Election Guide">[http://www.electionguide.org/country.php?ID=65 IFES Election Guide]</ref> it will be the second contested presidential election in Egypt's history. [[Hosni Mubarak]], the [[incumbent]] [[Rulers and heads of state of Egypt|President of Egypt]], may not run for this election which opens the door for many names to be suggested to take his place as President of Egypt. Some of those names are [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] (the ex-Director General of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA), and the winner of the 2005 [[Nobel Peace Prize]]), [[Amr Moussa]] (the current [[Secretary-General]] of the [[League of Arab States]], and former [[Egypt]]ian [[Foreign Minister]]), [[Ahmed Zewail]] ([[Egyptians|Egyptian]]-[[United States|American]] scientist, and the winner of the 1999 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]]), and [[Gamal Mubarak]] (the General Secretary of the Policy Committee of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] and the younger of the two sons of Hosni Mubarak), among others. Leading figures in the [[History of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] has refused to go into Egypt's presidential election even if they get the legal requirements <ref name="Leading figures in the Muslim Brotherhood: We will not go into Egypt's presidential election, even if we got the legal requirements">[http://www.aawsat.com/details.asp?section=4&issueno=10684&article=460508&feature= Leading figures in the Muslim Brotherhood: We will not go into Egypt's presidential election, even if we got the legal requirements]</ref> and refused women and Copts run for presidency again <ref name="Muslim Brotherhood refuse women and Copts run for presidency again">[http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=146188 Muslim Brotherhood refuse women and Copts run for presidency again]</ref>.
